speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. A street.

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Enter Judges, Senators and Tribunes, with MARTIUS  and QUINTUS, bound, passing on to the place of execution; TITUS going before, pleading

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Hear me, grave fathers! noble tribunes, stay!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For pity of mine age, whose youth was spent

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: In dangerous wars, whilst you securely slept;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For all my blood in Rome's great quarrel shed;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For all the frosty nights that I have watch'd;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And for these bitter tears, which now you see

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Filling the aged wrinkles in my cheeks;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Be pitiful to my condemned sons,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Whose souls are not corrupted as 'tis thought.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For two and twenty sons I never wept,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Because they died in honour's lofty bed.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lieth down; the Judges,  and c., pass by him, and Exeunt

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For these, these, tribunes, in the dust I write

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My heart's deep languor and my soul's sad tears:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Let my tears stanch the earth's dry appetite;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My sons' sweet blood will make it shame and blush.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O earth, I will befriend thee more with rain,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That shall distil from these two ancient urns,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Than youthful April shall with all his showers:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: In summer's drought I'll drop upon thee still;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: In winter with warm tears I'll melt the snow

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And keep eternal spring-time on thy face,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: So thou refuse to drink my dear sons' blood.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter LUCIUS, with his sword drawn

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O reverend tribunes! O gentle, aged men!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Unbind my sons, reverse the doom of death;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And let me say, that never wept before,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My tears are now prevailing orators.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O noble father, you lament in vain:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The tribunes hear you not; no man is by;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And you recount your sorrows to a stone.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ah, Lucius, for thy brothers let me plead.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Grave tribunes, once more I entreat of you,--

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My gracious lord, no tribune hears you speak.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why, tis no matter, man; if they did hear,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: They would not mark me, or if they did mark,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: They would not pity me, yet plead I must;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Therefore I tell my sorrows to the stones;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Who, though they cannot answer my distress,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Yet in some sort they are better than the tribunes,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For that they will not intercept my tale:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: When I do weep, they humbly at my feet

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Receive my tears and seem to weep with me;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, were they but attired in grave weeds,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Rome could afford no tribune like to these.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A stone is soft as wax,--tribunes more hard than stones;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A stone is silent, and offendeth not,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And tribunes with their tongues doom men to death.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Rises

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But wherefore stand'st thou with thy weapon drawn?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To rescue my two brothers from their death:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: For which attempt the judges have pronounced

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My everlasting doom of banishment.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O happy man! they have befriended thee.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why, foolish Lucius, dost thou not perceive

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That Rome is but a wilderness of tigers?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tigers must prey, and Rome affords no prey

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But me and mine: how happy art thou, then,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: From these devourers to be banished!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But who comes with our brother Marcus here?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter MARCUS and LAVINIA

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Titus, prepare thy aged eyes to weep;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or, if not so, thy noble heart to break:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I bring consuming sorrow to thine age.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Will it consume me? let me see it, then.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This was thy daughter.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why, Marcus, so she is.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Ay me, this object kills me!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Faint-hearted boy, arise, and look upon her.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Speak, Lavinia, what accursed hand

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Hath made thee handless in thy father's sight?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What fool hath added water to the sea,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or brought a faggot to bright-burning Troy?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My grief was at the height before thou camest,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And now like Nilus, it disdaineth bounds.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Give me a sword, I'll chop off my hands too;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For they have fought for Rome, and all in vain;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And they have nursed this woe, in feeding life;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: In bootless prayer have they been held up,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And they have served me to effectless use:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now all the service I require of them

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Is that the one will help to cut the other.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Tis well, Lavinia, that thou hast no hands;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For hands, to do Rome service, are but vain.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Speak, gentle sister, who hath martyr'd thee?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, that delightful engine of her thoughts

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That blabb'd them with such pleasing eloquence,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Is torn from forth that pretty hollow cage,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Where, like a sweet melodious bird, it sung

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sweet varied notes, enchanting every ear!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O, say thou for her, who hath done this deed?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, thus I found her, straying in the park,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Seeking to hide herself, as doth the deer

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That hath received some unrecuring wound.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: It was my deer; and he that wounded her

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Hath hurt me more than had he killed me dead:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For now I stand as one upon a rock

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Environed with a wilderness of sea,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Who marks the waxing tide grow wave by wave,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Expecting ever when some envious surge

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Will in his brinish bowels swallow him.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This way to death my wretched sons are gone;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Here stands my other son, a banished man,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And here my brother, weeping at my woes.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But that which gives my soul the greatest spurn,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Is dear Lavinia, dearer than my soul.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Had I but seen thy picture in this plight,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: It would have madded me: what shall I do

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now I behold thy lively body so?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thou hast no hands, to wipe away thy tears:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Nor tongue, to tell me who hath martyr'd thee:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thy husband he is dead: and for his death

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thy brothers are condemn'd, and dead by this.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Look, Marcus! ah, son Lucius, look on her!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: When I did name her brothers, then fresh tears

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Stood on her cheeks, as doth the honey-dew

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Upon a gather'd lily almost wither'd.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Perchance she weeps because they kill'd her husband;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Perchance because she knows them innocent.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: If they did kill thy husband, then be joyful

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Because the law hath ta'en revenge on them.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: No, no, they would not do so foul a deed;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Witness the sorrow that their sister makes.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Gentle Lavinia, let me kiss thy lips.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or make some sign how I may do thee ease:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Shall thy good uncle, and thy brother Lucius,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And thou, and I, sit round about some fountain,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Looking all downwards to behold our cheeks

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: How they are stain'd, as meadows, yet not dry,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: With miry slime left on them by a flood?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And in the fountain shall we gaze so long

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Till the fresh taste be taken from that clearness,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And made a brine-pit with our bitter tears?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or shall we cut away our hands, like thine?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or shall we bite our tongues, and in dumb shows

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Pass the remainder of our hateful days?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What shall we do? let us, that have our tongues,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Plot some deuce of further misery,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To make us wonder'd at in time to come.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sweet father, cease your tears; for, at your grief,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: See how my wretched sister sobs and weeps.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Patience, dear niece. Good Titus, dry thine eyes.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ah, Marcus, Marcus! brother, well I wot

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thy napkin cannot drink a tear of mine,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For thou, poor man, hast drown'd it with thine own.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Ah, my Lavinia, I will wipe thy cheeks.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Mark, Marcus, mark! I understand her signs:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Had she a tongue to speak, now would she say

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That to her brother which I said to thee:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: His napkin, with his true tears all bewet,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Can do no service on her sorrowful cheeks.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, what a sympathy of woe is this,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: As far from help as Limbo is from bliss!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter AARON

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Titus Andronicus, my lord the emperor

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Sends thee this word,--that, if thou love thy sons,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Let Marcus, Lucius, or thyself, old Titus,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Or any one of you, chop off your hand,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And send it to the king: he for the same

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Will send thee hither both thy sons alive;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And that shall be the ransom for their fault.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O gracious emperor! O gentle Aaron!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Did ever raven sing so like a lark,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That gives sweet tidings of the sun's uprise?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: With all my heart, I'll send the emperor My hand:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Good Aaron, wilt thou help to chop it off?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Stay, father! for that noble hand of thine,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That hath thrown down so many enemies,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Shall not be sent: my hand will serve the turn:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My youth can better spare my blood than you;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And therefore mine shall save my brothers' lives.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Which of your hands hath not defended Rome,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And rear'd aloft the bloody battle-axe,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Writing destruction on the enemy's castle?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, none of both but are of high desert:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My hand hath been but idle; let it serve

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To ransom my two nephews from their death;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Then have I kept it to a worthy end.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Nay, come, agree whose hand shall go along,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: For fear they die before their pardon come.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My hand shall go.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: By heaven, it shall not go!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sirs, strive no more: such wither'd herbs as these

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Are meet for plucking up, and therefore mine.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sweet father, if I shall be thought thy son,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Let me redeem my brothers both from death.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, for our father's sake and mother's care,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now let me show a brother's love to thee.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Agree between you; I will spare my hand.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Then I'll go fetch an axe.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But I will use the axe.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exeunt LUCIUS and MARCUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come hither, Aaron; I'll deceive them both:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lend me thy hand, and I will give thee mine.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: [Aside]  If that be call'd deceit, I will be honest,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And never, whilst I live, deceive men so:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: But I'll deceive you in another sort,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And that you'll say, ere half an hour pass.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Cuts off TITUS's hand

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS and MARCUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now stay your strife: what shall be is dispatch'd.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Good Aaron, give his majesty my hand:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tell him it was a hand that warded him

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: From thousand dangers; bid him bury it

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: More hath it merited; that let it have.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: As for my sons, say I account of them

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: As jewels purchased at an easy price;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And yet dear too, because I bought mine own.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I go, Andronicus: and for thy hand

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Look by and by to have thy sons with thee.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Aside

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Their heads, I mean. O, how this villany

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Doth fat me with the very thoughts of it!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Let fools do good, and fair men call for grace.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Aaron will have his soul black like his face.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, here I lift this one hand up to heaven,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And bow this feeble ruin to the earth:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: If any power pities wretched tears,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To that I call!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To LAVINIA

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What, wilt thou kneel with me?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Do, then, dear heart; for heaven shall hear our prayers;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or with our sighs we'll breathe the welkin dim,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And stain the sun with fog, as sometime clouds

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: When they do hug him in their melting bosoms.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O brother, speak with possibilities,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And do not break into these deep extremes.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Is not my sorrow deep, having no bottom?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Then be my passions bottomless with them.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But yet let reason govern thy lament.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: If there were reason for these miseries,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Then into limits could I bind my woes:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: When heaven doth weep, doth not the earth o'erflow?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: If the winds rage, doth not the sea wax mad,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Threatening the welkin with his big-swoln face?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And wilt thou have a reason for this coil?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I am the sea; hark, how her sighs do blow!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: She is the weeping welkin, I the earth:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Then must my sea be moved with her sighs;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Then must my earth with her continual tears

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Become a deluge, overflow'd and drown'd;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For why my bowels cannot hide her woes,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But like a drunkard must I vomit them.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Then give me leave, for losers will have leave

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To ease their stomachs with their bitter tongues.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter a Messenger, with two heads and a hand

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Worthy Andronicus, ill art thou repaid

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: For that good hand thou sent'st the emperor.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Here are the heads of thy two noble sons;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And here's thy hand, in scorn to thee sent back;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Thy griefs their sports, thy resolution mock'd;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: That woe is me to think upon thy woes

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: More than remembrance of my father's death.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now let hot AEtna cool in Sicily,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And be my heart an ever-burning hell!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These miseries are more than may be borne.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To weep with them that weep doth ease some deal;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But sorrow flouted at is double death.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Ah, that this sight should make so deep a wound,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And yet detested life not shrink thereat!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That ever death should let life bear his name,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Where life hath no more interest but to breathe!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: LAVINIA kisses TITUS

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Alas, poor heart, that kiss is comfortless

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: As frozen water to a starved snake.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: When will this fearful slumber have an end?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now, farewell, flattery: die, Andronicus;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thou dost not slumber: see, thy two sons' heads,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thy warlike hand, thy mangled daughter here:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thy other banish'd son, with this dear sight

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Struck pale and bloodless; and thy brother, I,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Even like a stony image, cold and numb.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ah, now no more will I control thy griefs:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Rend off thy silver hair, thy other hand

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Gnawing with thy teeth; and be this dismal sight

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The closing up of our most wretched eyes;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now is a time to storm; why art thou still?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ha, ha, ha!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why dost thou laugh? it fits not with this hour.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why, I have not another tear to shed:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Besides, this sorrow is an enemy,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And would usurp upon my watery eyes

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And make them blind with tributary tears:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Then which way shall I find Revenge's cave?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For these two heads do seem to speak to me,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And threat me I shall never come to bliss

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Till all these mischiefs be return'd again

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Even in their throats that have committed them.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come, let me see what task I have to do.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: You heavy people, circle me about,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That I may turn me to each one of you,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And swear unto my soul to right your wrongs.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The vow is made. Come, brother, take a head;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And in this hand the other I will bear.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lavinia, thou shalt be employ'd: these arms!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Bear thou my hand, sweet wench, between thy teeth.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: As for thee, boy, go get thee from my sight;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thou art an exile, and thou must not stay:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Hie to the Goths, and raise an army there:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, if you love me, as I think you do,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Let's kiss and part, for we have much to do.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exeunt TITUS, MARCUS, and LAVINIA

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Farewell Andronicus, my noble father,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The wofull'st man that ever lived in Rome:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Farewell, proud Rome; till Lucius come again,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: He leaves his pledges dearer than his life:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Farewell, Lavinia, my noble sister;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O, would thou wert as thou tofore hast been!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: But now nor Lucius nor Lavinia lives

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: But in oblivion and hateful griefs.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: If Lucius live, he will requite your wrongs;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And make proud Saturnine and his empress

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Beg at the gates, like Tarquin and his queen.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Now will I to the Goths, and raise a power,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To be revenged on Rome and Saturnine.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exit
